Key Arguments: The Bill risks censorship, outweighing any potential positive objectives.
It will remove transparency and accountability necessary for a democratic society.
It inhibits intellectual freedom and the free dissemination of information.
The Bill poses a danger by potentially withholding evidence-based information.
It could reduce trust in government information.
The legislation undermines democracy and hinders free expression.
There is potential for conflicts of interest and subjective interpretation of 'serious harm'.
The definitions of 'misinformation and disinformation' may change over time.
Notable Quotes: Any potential positive objective of the Bill is outweighed by the risk of censorship.
Freedom of speech and the freedom of choice must not be taken away.
